titleStmt.title: America needs her own poems
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Edward Grier writes that the handwriting of this manuscript is "similar to that of early notebooks," probably indicating a date "in the 1850s or earlier" (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 4:1587).

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: "America needs her own poems, in her own body and spirit"
bibl.orgName: Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

On the back of the manuscript are draft lines that contributed both to the poem ultimately titled "Thoughts [Of these years I sing...]" and to "Apostroph," the opening section of "Chants Democratic and Native American." Both poems first appeared in the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass.

revisionDesc.change: checked, changed two add insertions to add lassos, changed from ab to paragraph

body.p: America needs her own poems, in her own spirit body and spirit, different from all the rest hitherto—freer,, more muscular, than the any hitherto comprehending more, and unspeakably grander.—Not the importations, or any thing in the spirit of the importations aloof and in These States exiles;—not the superb, chronicles, faultless, and rich, perennial as they are and deserve to be in their native lands from of the past events and characters of Europe—nothing f not the current products of imaginative persons, with tropes, likenesses, piano music, and smooth rhymes—nor of
